Purpose in Architecture: Central storage for raw and transformed data. Acts as data lake.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Scalable, durable (11 nines), cost-effective, integrates natively with all AWS analytics tools.
Best Fit For Use Case: Ideal for storing structured, semi-structured, and unstructured data at scale.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: EFS or FSx (for file systems) — not as scalable for data lake.

Purpose in Architecture: ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) service to clean, transform, and catalog data.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Serverless ETL, auto-scales, deeply integrates with S3, Athena, and Redshift.
Best Fit For Use Case: Ideal for data preparation and building data catalogs automatically.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: AWS Data Pipeline, EMR, Apache Spark on EC2 — but require more management and cost.

Purpose in Architecture: Central metadata repository for datasets.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Automatically integrates with Glue, Athena, Redshift Spectrum.
Best Fit For Use Case: Enables schema discovery and queryability across multiple tools.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Apache Hive Metastore — less integrated and requires manual setup.

Purpose in Architecture: Interactive query service to analyze S3 data using SQL.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Serverless, no infrastructure, pay-per-query, and integrates directly with Glue Data Catalog.
Best Fit For Use Case: Perfect for ad-hoc querying of S3 data without loading into a database.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Redshift Spectrum, Presto, or EMR — require more cost or admin overhead.

Purpose in Architecture: Relational database for processed/curated data used by APIs.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Fully managed, highly available, 5x faster than standard PostgreSQL.
Best Fit For Use Case: Great for transactional workloads and serving structured data to APIs.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: RDS PostgreSQL (less scalable), DynamoDB (NoSQL – not relational).

Purpose in Architecture: Executes serverless functions for asynchronous processing and API integration.
Why Chosen (Strengths): No server management, scales automatically, event-driven execution.
Best Fit For Use Case: Ideal for lightweight logic between Aurora, APIs, and S3.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: ECS Fargate (containerized compute – overkill for small functions).

Purpose in Architecture: Visualization and BI dashboarding tool.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Serverless BI, integrates with Athena, Aurora, and S3.
Best Fit For Use Case: Great for self-service analytics and data visualization.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Power BI, Tableau – require separate licensing and integration.

Purpose in Architecture: Securely manage access and permissions across AWS resources.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Centralized, fine-grained control, integrates natively with all AWS services.
Best Fit For Use Case: Ensures principle of least privilege and secure data access.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Custom authentication or AD Federation – adds complexity.

Purpose in Architecture: Encrypts data at rest and in transit using managed keys.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Fully managed encryption, integrates with S3, Aurora, Glue, and more.
Best Fit For Use Case: Ensures compliance and data protection across AWS.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: CloudHSM (hardware security – costlier and complex).

Purpose in Architecture: Provides secure API access for Benefits and Claims APIs.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Serverless, scalable, integrates with Lambda and Aurora.
Best Fit For Use Case: Ideal for exposing backend services securely to external apps.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: EC2-hosted APIs, Kong Gateway – require more maintenance.

Purpose in Architecture: Open table format for huge analytical datasets on AWS.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Enables ACID transactions and schema evolution on S3.
Best Fit For Use Case: Ideal for scalable and reliable data lakes.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Delta Lake or Hudi – similar but different feature sets.

Purpose in Architecture: Purpose in Architecture
Why Chosen (Strengths): Why Chosen (Strengths)
Best Fit For Use Case: Best Fit For Use Case
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs

AWS Service / Component: Azure Data Lake Storage (via MS Fabric)
Purpose in Architecture: Central storage for raw and processed data (data lake).
Why Chosen (Strengths): Scalable, secure, cost-effective cloud storage with hierarchical namespace; integrates natively with Fabric and Synapse.
Best Fit For Use Case: Ideal for storing structured/unstructured data at scale for analytics workloads.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Azure Blob Storage (simpler, less suited for analytics); on-prem Hadoop HDFS (not cloud native).

Purpose in Architecture: Data ingestion and orchestration service to extract, transform, and load data.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Fully managed ETL with drag-and-drop UI; integrates with 90+ data sources and Fabric.
Best Fit For Use Case: Automates data movement between on-prem/cloud with low maintenance.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Logic Apps (for event workflows), Synapse Pipelines (less flexible for hybrid data).

Purpose in Architecture: Data engineering, transformation, and machine learning platform.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Unified Apache Spark environment with autoscaling and Delta Lake integration; collaborative notebooks.
Best Fit For Use Case: Best for large-scale data prep, cleaning, and transformation using Python/SQL/Scala.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Synapse Spark Pools (tighter Fabric integration but less flexible), HDInsight (requires more management).

AWS Service / Component: MS Fabric (OneLake, Data Warehouse, Data Engineering)
Purpose in Architecture: Unified SaaS analytics platform integrating data lake, ETL, and BI.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Combines capabilities of Synapse, Power BI, and Data Factory into one platform; no infrastructure management.
Best Fit For Use Case: End-to-end data analytics lifecycle (storage → transformation → visualization).
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Synapse Analytics + Power BI + ADF (modular but more complex setup).

Purpose in Architecture: Provides ACID transactions, schema enforcement, and time travel on data lake.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Ensures reliable data consistency and easy rollback; optimizes big data performance.
Best Fit For Use Case: Ideal for maintaining consistent data lake architecture with versioning.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Apache Iceberg, Apache Hudi — similar capabilities but less native Azure support.

Purpose in Architecture: Orchestrates workflows across ETL, data lake, and warehouse.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Low-code orchestration layer integrated with Fabric and ADF; built-in lineage and monitoring.
Best Fit For Use Case: Streamlines complex data transformations and scheduling.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: ADF pipelines (more flexibility but outside Fabric ecosystem).

Purpose in Architecture: Securely stores and manages secrets, encryption keys, and credentials.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Centralized secret management integrated with ADF, Databricks, and Fabric.
Best Fit For Use Case: Ensures compliance and data protection in multi-service architecture.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Azure Managed HSM (hardware security module — more costly and complex).

Purpose in Architecture: Central identity and access management for Azure services.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Enables single sign-on, MFA, and RBAC; integrates seamlessly across Azure.
Best Fit For Use Case: Ensures controlled access for users, APIs, and services.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: On-prem AD with Federation — adds latency and maintenance.

Purpose in Architecture: Defines fine-grained access to Azure resources.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Built-in, integrates with AAD; supports least-privilege principles.
Best Fit For Use Case: Essential for secure multi-tenant or enterprise workloads.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Custom IAM implementations — riskier and harder to maintain.

Purpose in Architecture: Manages, secures, and scales APIs (Claims & Benefits APIs).
Why Chosen (Strengths): Centralized API gateway with caching, throttling, and analytics.
Best Fit For Use Case: Simplifies secure exposure of backend services to web/mobile clients.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Azure Front Door or Application Gateway — more suited for web traffic, not APIs.

Purpose in Architecture: Provides unified and flexible API interface for personalized video content (via SundaySky).
Why Chosen (Strengths): Efficient data fetching; enables personalized user experiences with fewer calls.
Best Fit For Use Case: Ideal for custom member experience where multiple data sources are queried dynamically.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: REST API — simpler but less efficient for dynamic frontends.

Purpose in Architecture: Data visualization and business intelligence platform.
Why Chosen (Strengths): Native integration with Fabric; supports semantic models and real-time dashboards.
Best Fit For Use Case: Best for self-service analytics, KPI dashboards, and executive reporting.
Possible Alternatives & Trade-offs: Alternatives: Tableau, Qlik Sense — strong visualization but external integration required.
